title: Filing Taxes Could Be Free and Simple. But H&R Block and Intuit Are Still Lobbying Against It.

last_post.content:
As I sit here trying to fill out my US taxes, I want to remind everyone in the USA that the fault that you have to suffer figuring out how to file your taxes lies entirely with the tax preparation industry.

"The makers of TurboTax and other online systems spent millions lobbying last year, much of it directed toward a bill that would permanently bar the government from offering taxpayers prefilled filings."

https://www.propublica.org/article/filing-taxes-could-be-free-simple-hr-block-intuit-lobbying-against-it

Income taxes could be like car registration or property taxes where the government just sends you a statement and a bill or refund at the end of the year.

title: Five Voting Laws Needed To Protect Democracy

last_post.content:
Five Voting Laws Needed To Protect Democracy
1. Ban voter challenges.
2. Prevent long lines.
3. Limit partisan poll watchers.
4. Strengthen the vote counting and election certification process.
5. Require courts to prioritize protecting voting rights.

I love the phrase "the lesser" and want to claim it for myself

Like, before I enter any room, I want to be referred to as "Clive the Lesser" -- as in "hark, I see the approach of Clive the Lesser"

It implies the existence of Clive the Greater, whose capabilities I wonder about

The 10th annual international Gender Census 2023 is now open until at least 9th May 2023!

https://survey.gendercensus.com

It's for anyone whose gender (or lack thereof) isn't described by the M/F binary. It's short and easy, and results are useful in academia, business and self-advocacy.

You know what? I think Oquonie is complete.

For the past two months @rek and I ported a game of ours for its 10th years anniversary since iOS updates broke it beyond repair.

It has been rewritten to target a virtual machine, which should(hopefully) help us keeping it playable. In the next few days I'll release a document that explains how to write an emulator to run the game.

get emulator: https://100r.co/site/uxn.html
get source: https://git.sr.ht/~rabbits/oquonie

If anyone has a secret mobile phone hidden from an abusive partner, remember to switch off or put in airplane mode etc as described below, or the phone will be activated with the loud alert on the evening of 23/04.

Please share this to help keep others safe

The alert will say:

“This is a test of Emergency Alerts, a new UK government service that will warn you if there’s a life-threatening emergency nearby.

In an actual emergency, follow the instructions in the alert to keep yourself and others safe.

Visit gov.uk/alerts for more information.

This is a test. You do not need to take any action.”

Mobile phone masts in the surrounding area will broadcast an alert. Every compatible mobile phone or tablet in range of a mast will receive the alert.

Your mobile phone or tablet does not have to be connected to mobile data or wifi to get alerts.

You can opt out of emergency alerts, but the government advises you should keep them switched on for your own safety.

To opt out:

Search your settings for ‘emergency alerts’.
Turn off ‘severe alerts’ and ‘extreme alerts’.
If you still get alerts, contact your device manufacturer for help.

Refuge have produced a really helpful video @ https://lnkd.in/e-D7uJpF

title: Putin's Twitter account resurfaces as Russia comes in from the cold

last_post.content:
Over on the bad site, Twitter has lifted restrictions on Kremlin accounts and is no longer limiting the reach of Kremlin media accounts.

Russian government tweets are appearing in Twitter’s algorithmically-driven “For You” feed for newly created accounts, even when they did not follow them. So Twitter is not just *showing* these Kremlin accounts — it's algorithmically *boosting* them.

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2023/04/07/elon-musk-twitter-lifts-restrictions-putin-kremlin-russia/

Recently, I uploaded a video from Bell Laboratories, Inc. featuring the first example of synthesized computer speech. Regrettably, this was the first upload of mine to receive a copyright violation. However, this was not due to the content of the record itself, but rather due to someone who had sampled parts of the record and used them in their own song. As far as I understood, YouTube's copyright and content ID match requires original creations that do not contain samples from another recording.

I conducted research to determine who now owned all of Bell Labs' patents and copyrights and discovered that it was Nokia. I was able to submit a form for licensing requests via their website and explained the nature of my channel and the copyright problem I had encountered while trying to showcase their record on YouTube.

To my pleasant surprise, Nokia was incredibly accommodating and granted me a no-charge lifetime license, on the condition that I add the message "Courtesy of Nokia Corporation and AT&T Archives" to the video, which I was more than willing to do.

Unfortunately, this process required me to edit the video and re-upload it. However, it is now up once again, and the copyright has been filed with the claimant, including all details of the license I received from Nokia.

https://youtu.be/HVOo9bhcsH4

#Telephone #Nokia #AT&T #YouTube #Video #Record #Vinyl

“Two morsels of lumber”

I love the creative workarounds we use when we need to convey something in a language we don’t speak well. Why do we cringe when we do it ourselves? It should be admirable. Someone is thinking fast in divergent layers while under conversational pressure and has filled a gap in grammar or vocabulary in a functional, inventive way.

If you're on Mastodon, you might already know that it's #opensource, with folks actively reporting bugs and opening feature requests, and debating how to best implement them.

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues

Similarly, many apps are open-source as well, including the official ones for Android and iOS:

- https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon-android/issues
- https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon-ios/issues

You don't need programming experience to contribute in a meaningful way.

To my fellow disconnected members of neurodifferent.me, while I hope this issue gets resolved soon, I'd probably recommend exporting your current data just in case. This is so you can import some of your data into a different Mastodon instance/server.

To get the backup, you need to log into your account via the website, I don't think apps will work.

1: Sign in to https://neurodifferent.me
2: Go to https://neurodifferent.me/settings/export
3: At the bottom of that page, there should be an option to get an archive. It may take a few minutes, you should get an email when it's ready.
4: When ready, download the file to a safe place in case you need it in the future.

You can only do this once every seven days, so if you've done it in the past week, you'll probably be unable to export until enough time passes.

So like, I've been deep into Apple Web Standards positions for like 45 mins now. See https://github.com/orgs/WebKit/projects/1/views/1

TL;DR Apple is defending privacy and security so well against Google/others and I'm actually very impressed. It really reinforces my belief that Safari is the only acceptable browser on the market for privacy.

Also of note, it seems like Apple is now putting a lot more effort in adopting proposals that make sense than they used to.

If you're very interested in keeping up with Safari Web Standards support, I highly recommend @jensimmons for more :)

title: Metaphysical Animals by Clare Mac Cumhaill, Rachael Wiseman: 9780385545709 | PenguinRandomHouse.com: Books

last_post.content: Currently reading, and enjoying tremendously, Metaphysical Animals: How Four Women Brought Philosophy Back to Life. Highly recommend to those interested in #history #philosophy #biography #womenInAcademia or just a good read! #bookstodon. https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/617233/metaphysical-animals-by-clare-mac-cumhaill-and-rachael-wiseman/

My friend Steve Cummins has started a marketing podcast. The first episode features Charley Karpiuk who has an interesting take on whether/how to use GPT to write marketing material. For the time being, he says, people should write the things that people read. Reserve GPT for things (like SEO metadata) that machines read.

https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-marketing-mix/id1680813609

title: Virtual Metaverse Real Estate Is Completely in the Toilet

last_post.content:
"Virtual real estate platform Decentraland, once valued at $1 billion, is now in free fall. Revenues have absolutely cratered over the last year, The Block reports, with only a handful of users actually trading virtual real estate [...] The numbers are absolutely brutal. According to the report, only between 20 and 30 people are actually buying and selling property on a weekly basis, amounting to roughly $50,000."

https://futurism.com/the-byte/virtual-metaverse-real-estate-trouble

title: $388 in Sushi. Just a $20 Tip: The Brutal Math of Uber Eats and DoorDash

last_post.content: It’s time to get rid of tipping. In North America, service employers deliberately underpay servers and delivery people hoping we’ll make up the difference. But these employers often skim off these tips as well. Tips used to be about service, but now it’s just sanctioned wage theft. Employers should be forced to pay people what their labour is worth. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/09/business/uber-eats-door-dash-delivery-tips.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare

title: The Short Life and Humiliating Death of the Clipper Chip

last_post.content:
This month is the 30th anniversary of the announcement of the Clipper Chip, the first of many bad ideas for weakening cryptography with "key escrow" backdoors. Clipper is long dead, but its ghost continues to haunt us from time to time.

https://gizmodo.com/life-and-death-of-clipper-chip-encryption-backdoors-att-1850177832
